awd_titl_txt: CCRI: Planning-C: Federated Cloud Platform for Networked Cyber Physical Systems Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Networked Cyber-Physical Systems (NCPS) play an essential role in modern society by efficiently controlling and managing critical services. Such N-CPS' have noticeable advantages over traditional Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS), including ease of use and control, better services and system management, better resource utilization, ability to use Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) components, and improved reliability and fault-tolerant services at the cost of increased complexity. Adopting N-CPS adds challenges in cybersecurity, system development, systems management, and training, necessitating a federated cloud platform to support collaborative N-CPS research. This Federated Cloud Platform for Networked Cyber-Physical Systems (FCP-NCPS) will enable researchers to address N-CPS security, interoperability, management, and training challenges while enabling the creation of realistic datasets for research in data analytics and cybersecurity.

This planning grant will enable: 1) to organize research community and industry workshops in the Tucson Area, Baltimore Area, and Detroit Area to discuss the needs and exchange research ideas addressable through the FCP-NCPS; 2) Organizing workshops with teaching and K-12 schools in Tucson, Baltimore, and Detroit areas to discuss and understand their needs to impart training in CPS to their students. These activities will allow: 1) Creation of a community cloud platform for seamless integration of diverse CPS testbeds that are syntactically, semantically, and geographically separated for realistic experimentation to address N-CPS security, interoperability, management, and training challenges; 2) to develop a dataset collection framework integrated into the federated system to address the scarcity of realistic datasets in the fields of cybersecurity, and data analytics; 3) to provide a community infrastructure for imparting realistic, practical (hands-on) training to students to address the nation's N-CPS workforce requirements.

The FCP-NCPS being a scalable community research platform, will also find applications in different fields, including expanding interpretability and the trustworthiness of Artificial Intelligence (AI), experimentation of medical devices and medical training practices, and experimentation and evolution of autonomous systems, to name a few. Moreover, the proposed Federated Cloud Platform will aid the global research community (especially in the developing world) in performing realistic experimentation and evaluating their research ideas to advance the frontiers of science.

Information on FCP-NCPS is available at https://fcpncps.arizona.edu. This site will host all the content for the FCP-NCPS, including the project information, APIs, documentation, and datasets, for the duration of the project and three years after its termination. This project is a collaboration between the University of Arizona, University of Detroit-Mercy, Johns Hopkins University, and Riverside Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The development and adoption of these Networked Cyber Physical Systems (N-CPS) have increased the complexity, adding challenges in cybersecurity, system development, systems management, and training. Thus, there is a need for a Federated Cloud Platform to support collaborative N-CPS research that will enable: 1) Research of N-CPS’ and their interoperability; 2) Research of N-CPS’ security frameworks; 3) Research of N-CPS’ management policies (including Software Assurance); 4) Research on N-CPS’ training and education programs; 5) Development of realistic datasets from federated systems to enable research in data analytics and cyber security; 6) Integration of diverse geographically dispersed CPS systems into the Federation for increased community research infrastructure sharing and collaboration. This project focused on the planning activities towards the design and development of a Federated Cloud Platform to support collaborative Networked Cyber-Physical Systems (N-CPS) to address the challenges mentioned above.

The primary goals of this planning effort were to: 1) Introduce the research community to the FCP-NCPS collaborative research platform, 2) Understand community needs that can be addressed by the FCP-NCPS, 3) Discuss the potential challenges that the community foresees with the FCP-NCPS architecture, and building plan, 4) Identify and discuss best practices that will improve the building and the future operations of the FCP-NCPS, 5) Build a community of CPS testbed operators that will join the infrastructure, and 6) Build a community of users who will use the infrastructure once built.

The key outcomes of this planning effort are: 1) Planning Workshops: After initial planning phase, the team hosted three workshops in Tucson, Detroit, and Baltimore reaching out to the community of researchers, educators, and industry partners; 2) Workshop discussions: During the workshops, there was a strong and healthy discussion on the planning themes that ranged from CPS research testbed design and operation challenges to the potential application of the proposed infrastructure to address industry workforce development challenges; 3) CIRC Proposal Submission: The planning effort resulted in improvement of the proposed FCP-NCPS design and architecture, that resulted in a NSF Community Infrastructure for Research in Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CIRC) development proposal called CIRC: Dev: Federated Cloud Platform for Networked Cyber Physical Systems Research in September 2023, 4) Cybersecurity Education: This planning effort resulted in extensive discussions with the industry partners to understand their needs and challenges; especially with training and workforce development. These discussions partially enabled submitting of a funded NSF Eager proposal (NSF-2335046) to address cybersecurity workforce needs.
